The first part benefited, i believe, from having only 13 episodes. This sequel suffered from it. Not in the sense that it was rushed, but in the one that they had too much time. (i gave the first season a 9 btw) Over the course of the review, i try to contrast what made the first season great and this season suck, and to anyone who hasn't watched it, i definitely recommend the first. The second maybe only for completion's sake.
To use the cliched phrase, as much as i hate it, the original K 'showed' and didn't tell. Much of the enjoyment i derived fromit was from its reluctance to just hand me everything on a plate and have me try to read into what was being shown. While the sequel tries to do the same at times, most others, it just punches you in the face with what it wants to say. The most infuriating part? More often than not, it doesn't have anything to say. Atleast nothing we haven't heard already a thousand times (without going into details, its the same old crap about the strength of humans, and the belief that they can do the right thing...sigh, it basically became a shonen in the end, with all the bullshit ' i believe' and 'i dont need anyone other than friends' being thrown around)

It also doesn't help that the female characters are little more than a broken record that can repeat just the single line (especially the insufferable cat, i really hated her this time even more). Like seriously, while i didn't particularly mind the excessive fanservice at times, they are even lesser than 1-dimensional characters in terms of traits. This issue unfortunately spreads over to other characters that were quite good in terms of personality from the first season. Here, they just practically repeat the same lines over and over (looking at you Anna). If all the extra time was instead focused on characters like the blue king and...well only him i guess, it could have made things more interesting. After some thought, there are at most one or two who are interesting apart from him. Not exactly great for a show that has so many characters is it? But i guess you cant blame the show though. I feel like all that could have been explored in terms of character was done in the first season itself. So, this time they had to focus on more of the same (case in point: the red clan) or try to introduce a stupid conflict that was a nonentity anyways (the blue clan). Hence, why i feel they had too much time.

Now on the matter of plot. Its simplistic to say the least. Not that the first season was anything great in terms of complexity. But it wove multiple threads, revenge, coming to terms with past mistakes, trying to help a friend, all trite plot lines to be sure, but the execution was great. Also while the powers involved in the story themselves are grand, the plot felt grounded in more human emotions. This season it tries to be something more. But just fails epically at it, probably the only thing that was truly grand about it in the end anyway. That's about it without going into spoilers.


To go over the rest of the elements in brief. Animation is good. Sometimes too good. Enough so that a lot of times you can easily make out that they are reusing clips. And they reuse clips. A lot. And i mean a lot. Get it? A lot. Yeah, its that bad, that many 'lots'.

Art was good too. Really good designs and art choices. Not the colors though. It just felt strange sometimes.

Music kind of changed styles as well, became more dancy, helped the fights seem more like dances, which i think was what the directors were going for so it helped i guess. No particular standout songs though. 


Overall, a disappointment. While i had some fun, i would have much rather spent the time on some other series. If you're a fan of the first and can't help but have more, go ahead, maybe you'll feel differently. If you're reading this without ever having seen K for some reason, go right ahead and watch the first. The first. And maybe forget the second exists before its too late.


(Whew, that was long i think. thanks for reading. maybe i should keep a tl;dr version...)

It's hard to determine exactly how I feel about the second season of K. Right from the go the second season has a completely different atmosphere than the first -- removing what made it special. 
The first season was almost more about the mystery than anything else. The presentation, atmosphere and direction all felt unique, albeit off-putting at times. It was a clever blend of randomness and showmanship that kept the audience engaged.
Which is precisely why the direction the second season takes doesn't come as a total surprise. Instead of being cleverly unique, from the beginning the second season is a completely over-produced, hyper-stylized train-wreck.


The amazing sound design (/soundtrack) come back strong, but don't seem to match the atmosphere of the series at all. While I still adore the added music in-of itself, it simply feels like a jumbled mess that doesn't blend together well.


The story also loses what makes it special. The mysterious MC from the first season now accomplishes nearly nothing, and even when he finally attempts to, it feels completely unsatisfying. And all the side characters that had been justly treated in the first season, with their own sub-plots presented compellingly, are just kind of there this time around. Nothing much happens with them, and the story is pretty much just focused on its linear narrative.


This is only made even more abundantly clear with the reduction of all the female cast (of any significance) to straight-up, borderline sex dolls. They have no significant contribution to anything this time around, minus a gimmie here or there, but remain prevalent only for the purpose of many a fan-service shot. 


It seems like they cranked everything up to 11 this time around, but somehow stripped the series of the depth it had in the first season, making it feel like a try-hard copycat. Many of the moving-camera shots even started to make me feel nauseous, especially when it's just one after another. 


I have no idea what went on behind the scenes between the movie and the second season, but this is a serious disappointment. Which, again, isn't a terrible surprise as the first season seems to be a perfect storm that probably had no right to be as good as it was. 


I probably would have been better off having NOT re-watched the first season (and movie) in preparation for the second, but alas my opinion on the series is going to lie where it may. Based on my personal experience, I can't legitimately recommend the second season (or the first movie for that matter) as its hard to not draw comparisons between it and the first. 


However, I do feel others may have more fun with the second season than I did. Its pomp and circumstance is likely welcome when not watching all 13 episodes back-to-back and it still has a few impactful scenes that made it enjoyable overall.

K: Return of Kings is the final installment of the K: Project Series. This is a pretty typical shounen anime, but I love shounen anime, so I may be a bit biased here. 
(This is a no spoilers review)
Story:
Return of Kings picks up where Missing Kings (the movie) left off, with Kuro and Neko waiting/searching for Shiro. The main antogonist of this season is the Green King, and Shiro and the gang will have to pull out all the stops in order to match the super powerful Green King. The story seemlessly continues on the path the last two installments began, and the main plotof this season is fully thought out and well rounded.


Art:


Return of Kings has absolutely breathtaking art. All the character designs and scenery from the first two series is amped up and pushed to the limit, producing gorgeous fight scenes that literally take your breath away. The colors and fluidity of animation are truly awesome. This category gets a 10.


Sound:


Another category that wins a 10 from me. The last two installments had pretty good music and sound, but Return of Kings takes this to a whole new level. The "jazzy" feeling that I disliked in the first series has been replaced by upbeat, techno sounding music that really helped each scene. The fight scenes feel particularly fresh and engaging.


Character:


This show has A LOT of characters, but one of the things K is so good at is making you care about most, if not all of them. Each character is given enough screen time to feel fleshed out. Our main characters were of course given the most screen time, but not quite as much as I would have liked - I would have liked to have seen a lot more of Shiro and Kuro.


TDLR::

Overall I really enjoyed Return of Kings. The story is well rounded, the characters fleshed out, the music and art are superb, and the show concludes nicely. If you are a fan of K, you will not be disappointed with this second series and with how it ends.

K: Return of Kings is the long anticipated sequel of the anime K and the movie K: Missing Kings. It closely follows the style of its predecessors as a hot-blooded story about the tragedy aroused out of the differences in ideologies and the value of friendship coupled with quite a bit of Ho Yay (which is, to sidetrack a bit, part of the reason why I know this show). Its strengths and weaknesses are also similar to them, having excellent aesthetical attraction but merely mediocre plot.
The biggest appeal of the K franchise is its visual design, thanks to its generous budget. The scenery is gorgeous,to speak the least, and every character is visually attractive while having their distinctive designs. The only minor flaw is the 3D animations that may look awkward when juxtaposed against the 2D characters. I can't say whether all the panty shots and gainaxing makes the anime better or worse - I am not a big fan of fanservice, but your mileage may vary.


To add to the aesthetic value of the show, the aural effects are also good, if not outright excellent. The seiyuu is an all-star cast - we have Daisuke Ono (who voiced Sebastian) for Kuro, Mamoru Miyano (who voiced Light Yagami) for Fushimi, Jun Fukuyama (who voiced Lelouch vi Britannia) for Misaki, etc - and there is no doubt that all of them successfully bring out the emotions of the characters The background music is in a variety of genres including soft piano , electronic, orchestral, so on and so forth. The OP, Asymmetry by Yui Horie, is a typical J-Pop song while the ED, Solution by CustomiZ, is a more hardcore rock that suits the badass feeling of the anime. The soundtrack is probably inferior to shows like Puella Magi Madoka Magica and Steins; Gate, but that doesn't mean it is bad either.


Not so, however, when it comes to the story. The numerous logical leaps and are also an eyesore. For example, how can Yashiro leap down for 3 episodes before landing at the exact right spot for a big damn heroes moment? Why can Kuro, even after the Dresden Plate is dealt with, still retain their power for some time? Why is Reisi suddenly empowered to beat his opponent, despite failing epically in the previous match? These flaws, accompanied with the hand-waved explanation, render the story mediocre at best.


The characters somewhat compensate for the mediocre story, but one needs to look at the side materials in order to truly appreciate them. The net result of having loads and loads of character is that each of them can only have a day under limelight, if any. Yashiro unfortunately received a huge badass decay when it comes to his guile and fighting skills, which is evident in how he manages the siege in Episode 6-8 by literally flying around. This can be explained by his pacifist nature, but it isn't clear on first sight. The Silver Clan receives little development. The motive behind the main antagonist, while more or less depicted in the side manga, is not clearly elaborated in the anime. HOMRA and Scepter 4 are also hosts of many interesting characters, but to truly appreciate them, side materials are, again, necessary. Especially Scepter 4 - the only people I can remember in the anime are Reisi, Seri and Fushimi. However, if you read the Days of Blue novella, you will soon see every character is idiosyncratic in one way or another, and their relationship is both professional and friendly.


Fortunately, the fleshed out characters and the well-constructed fighting scenes compensate for the above problems to make the show enjoyable overall. This show is not as much a melodrama as one may think at first, but one needs to rely on side materials and deeper appreciation in order to realize it.

!!!!!!!!!!![SPOILER ALERT]!!!!!!!!!!!
Okay, this season is totally different from the first one for many reasons. Generally it does not suck very bad but there are few points that you should be aware of that made this season less liked for me than the first season: 
1. The Background Music: It does not suck only it sucks much, I mean techno music made the situation more than funny to me, and many of the times the music was not on the right time or not appealing at least. 
2. The story: The kings thing is cool yet far from the first season even if we did nottry to compare it to the previous season it still far from perfect. The story does not seem well plotted and there are many fillers during the episodes that left all the good action to the last two eps (12 & 13) which was not even enough! The green kings are fine and I liked their characters however, they were defeated so easily at the end.  In addition, the episodes lost the taste of connection together which for me did not seem quite good.\n
3. The Enjoyment: it was fair because no much of enjoyment there unless you are looking for Neko's panties...that's a different story then. \n
4. The characters are quire good and the anime art is goodish, however there is more (not required) fan service in there.\n\n
In general, it was fine watching this season and I want to say it was totally not what I expected to see from the awesome K I used to know!
